ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Enhancement of the thermal properties of silver-diamond composites with chromium carbide coating

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Department of Mathematics, College of Science
Department of Chemistry, College of Science

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: The present work reports the enhancement of the thermal properties in Ag/diamond matrix composites reinforced with chromium carbide coated diamond particles. The coated diamond particles were characterized by x-ray diffraction, x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and Raman spectra. The composites were synthesized by spark plasma sintering. The chromium carbide coating on the diamond particles resulted in composites exhibiting improved wettability and strong interfacial bonding between the diamond particles and Ag matrix. The composites with coated diamonds showed a low coefficient of thermal expansion of 8.24 × 10−6/K and a high thermal conductivity of 695 W/mK at 60 % particle volume fraction, which greatly outperformed the composites with uncoated diamonds at the same particle volume fraction. The obtained results are useful for synthesizing Ag/diamond composites with greatly improved thermal performance.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Rapid development of advanced microprocessors and electronic devices brings about continuous reduction in device size and increment in power density. Therefore, thermal management becomes a challenge with the miniaturization of electronic device. High thermal conductivity (TC) and low coefficient of thermal expansion (CTE) are in great need for thermal management materials (TMCs) to facilitate the heat dissipation and relieve the thermal stress [1]. The traditional TMCs such as CuW(Mo), Al(Cu)/SiC are not able to meet the future requirements in thermal management due to various drawbacks of these materials such as very high density for CuW(Mo), insufficient thermal performance for Al(Cu)/SiC [2].

Diamond is known to have the ultrahigh TC, in the range of 1,200–2,000 W/mK [3]. Embedding diamond particles in a metal matrix such as Al, Cu or Ag provides a way to dissipate heat to the maximal degree [4–6]. Recently, there has been an increasing interest in the development of these metal/diamond composites which have a great potential for the application in laser diodes, microprocessors of laptops. However, there are still some obstacles in terms of densification and interfacial adhesion, which hinder the common acceptance of metal/diamond composites as alterative TMCs with outstanding thermal properties. Currently, the major limitation to fully explore the efficiency of high TC diamond particles and their underperformance in comparison with the theoretical predictions originate from the lack of a well bonded interface between the metal matrix and diamond particles owing to their poor wettability [7]. Poor wetting will lead to a high interfacial thermal resistance, which results in a great phonon scattering at the interface and subsequently leads to a significant degradation in the effective TC of the composites. An effective way known as matrix-alloying, namely by addition of carbide-forming elements such as Cr [6], B [8] and Zr [9] into metal matrix, can effectively promote wetting and interfacial bonding between the diamond particles and metal matrix. Nevertheless, the alloying elements always remain in the metal matrix and can act as scattering points, resulting in great decrease in matrix TC, in turn leading to a much reduced TC of the composites. On the other hand, the pre-coating of diamond particles or surface-metallization method is found to efficiently improve the interfacial bonding and the whole TC of the composites. By incorporation of Cr-, B- and W-coated diamonds, the metal/diamond composites exhibit high TC of 300–900 W/mK [8, 10].

Carbides usually have many applications owing to their properties such as high hardness, high melting point, excellent resistance to chemical corrosion [11]. Several works have shown that carbide coatings such as TiC and Mo2C on diamonds can effectively strengthen the interfacial bonding and induce the high-efficiency TC enhancement in Cu/diamond and Al/diamond composites [12, 13]. Inspired by these encouraging results, we expect that this pre-coating of diamond particles by carbides can thus provide an effective way for efficient integration of diamond particles into metal composites exhibiting enhanced thermal properties. However, to the best of our knowledge, the use of carbide coating to improve the thermal properties of Ag/diamond composites has not yet been investigated.

The present work reports the enhancement of the thermal properties in Ag/diamond matrix composites reinforced with chromium carbide coated diamond particles. The coated diamond particles were characterized by x-ray diffraction (XRD), x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and Raman spectra. The chromium carbide coating was firstly synthesized by a molten salt method and then incorporated into the Ag matrix to fabricate bulk Ag/diamond composites by spark plasma sintering (SPS). The thermal properties of the composites using diamond particles with and without chromium carbide coating in terms of TC and CTE were analyzed both experimentally and theoretically.

Section1.Heading: Experimental
Section1.Para: Ag powder (99.9 % in purity) with ~10 μm was used as the composite matrix. The diamond particles were synthetic MBD-6 diamonds with a mean size of ~85 μm. Chromium carbide coating was applied on the surfaces of the diamond particles using a reported molten salt method [14]. The starting mixed powders with three volume fractions 50, 55 and 60 % were dry mixed at room temperature using a three-dimensional vibratory mill for 150 min. The milling balls were not used since the ultra-high hardness of diamond particles could wear the surface of the balls during the mixing process, which could bring impurities of balls into powders. The mixed powders were sintered by SPS system (Dr. Sinter 2080, SPS Syntex Inc., Japan) at a temperature of 800 °C for 5 min in a vacuum of ~10−3Pa under a pressure of 50 MPa. These SPS parameters ensured that we maintained the same matrix microstructure phase composition and high density (>99 % theoretical density) for all the SPS consolidated specimens. For comparison, the pure Ag specimens and Ag/diamond composites with uncoated diamond particles were also fabricated under the same processing. For brevity, Ag/uncoated-diamond and Ag/coated-diamond are used to represent two types of prepared composites, respectively. The temperature was measured and controlled using an optical pyrometer. Shrinkage, displacement, heating current and voltage were also recorded during the sintering processes.

The extreme hardness of the diamond particles prevents polishing the exterior surface of the composites. For this reason, fracture surface observation was used to investigate the microstructure of the composites. The samples were mechanically broken into two or more parts in order to allow investigation of the fracture surfaces by SEM. The XRD patterns were recorded with a XRD diffractometer operated with Cu Kα radiation (Shimadzu XRD-6000). XPS experiments were carried out on a RBD upgraded PHI-5000C ESCA system (Perkin Elmer) with MgK α radiation. Raman spectra were collected on a thermal dispersive spectrometer using a laser with an excitation wavelength of 633 nm at a laser power of 10 mW. The density of the composites was measured by Archimedes’ principle with distilled water as the medium. The theoretical densities of pure Ag (10.5 g/cm3) and diamond (3.52 g/cm3) were used to calculate the relative density of samples. All samples were within 99 % of the theoretical density. Thermomechanical analyzer (Q-400 TA Instruments) was used to measure the CTE of the specimens. The room temperature TC of the specimens was measured using a transient thermal flash technique.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussions
Section1.Para:
Figure 1 shows the morphology of the chromium carbide coated diamond particles. It is clear that the surface of diamonds is uniformly covered with the rough coating layer without any obvious cracks formed. The cross-section of the coated particles (inset of Fig. 1) shows that there is a good adhesion between the chromium carbide coating and the diamond particles. The thickness of the coating layer is determined as ~0.8 μm. Figure 2a shows the XRD patterns for the diamond particles with and without chromium carbide coating. As seen, the pure diamond particles show three diffraction peaks at 43.5°, 75.8° and 91.2° corresponding to d-spacing of (111), (220) and (311) [15], respectively. In the XRD pattern of coated diamond particles, additional small diffraction peaks can be indexed as the orthorhombic structured Cr7C3 (space group Pnma), which coincides well with the standard XRD data of Cr7C3 [16]. XRD results also show that no pure Cr or oxide peaks appear, indicating that nearly all Cr is changed into Cr7C3. The surface chemical state of coated particles is further verified by XPS, as shown in Fig. 2b. The high-resolution Cr 2p spectrum can be deconvoluted into two peaks of Cr 2p3/2 (577.9 eV) and Cr 2p1/2 (587.2 eV), which are in good agreement with the reported XPS characteristic of Cr7C3 [17] in consistence with XRD analysis. These results indicate that the reaction between the Cr powder and the surface of diamond takes place during the coating process. This reaction has been observed previously [7, 18], and it is considered that disordered carbons on diamond surface defects serve as carbon sources for reaction.
Fig. 1
Morphology of chromium carbide coated diamond particles (SEM, inset for the cross-section of the coated particles)
Fig. 2
a XRD patterns of uncoated diamond and coated diamond particles; b XPS Cr 2p spectrum of coated diamond particles

The Raman technique is a powerful non-destructive method for evaluating any changes in the structure of the carbon including diamond. Figure 3 shows Raman spectra of uncoated diamonds, coated diamonds and Ag/coated-diamond composites. It is clear that all the Raman spectra show a same characteristic peak of diamond (around 1,334 cm−1) [19]. All have nearly the same full width at half maximum of ~4 cm−1, and there is no change in either the magnitude or shape of the peaks from any of the processes (inset of Fig. 3), indicating that there are no changes or deformations in the molecular structure of the diamonds for any of the processes. Here, a very slight reduction of peak magnitude in Ag/coated-diamond composites is found, but it arises from the release of the residual stress of coated diamonds after sintering process. It is well-known that the general reason for a structural change in a diamond is the occurrence of graphitization. The graphitization of diamond has been found to be facilitated in the presence of a small amount of residual oxygen in the atmosphere surrounding diamond powders [4]. However, in the present case, the high vacuum degree of ~10−3Pa can effectively retard the reaction of diamond with oxygen and hence the diamond graphitization could be effectively avoided in the composite densification process. In addition, the coating layer is an advantage to protect the diamonds from oxidization and reduces the possibility of diamond graphitization at the sintering temperature.
Fig. 3
Raman spectra of uncoated diamonds, coated diamonds and Ag/coated-diamond composites (inset for high magnification of 1,334 cm−1 peak)

Figure 4 shows the typical SPS displacement as a function of sintering temperature for Ag/uncoated-diamond and Ag/coated-diamond composites. As seen, both composites exhibit two shrinkage steps. The first shrinkage step at about 200–400 °C shows a steady increase in displacement, which is attributed to the rearrangement of the Ag grains. In contrast, a sharp increase of displacement at the second shrinkage step of 750–850 °C corresponds to solid-state sintering [20]. Although the SPS mechanism of densification is still unclear, it is suggested that synergic effects of spark plasma, joule heating and electrical field diffusion contribute to the powder densification [20]. In addition, the onset solid-state sintering temperature of Ag/coated-diamond composites at around 750 °C is clearly lower than that of 800 °C for Ag/uncoated-diamond composites. This indicates that the coated diamonds facilitate the densification process such as the matrix grain rearrangement, Ag diffusion and grain growth, which is attributed to the improved wettability between the Ag matrix powders and coated diamonds.
Fig. 4
Displacement vs. temperature recorded during the SPS process for Ag/uncoated-diamond and Ag/coated-diamond composites

Figure 5 shows the SEM images of the fracture surfaces of Ag/uncoated-diamond and Ag/coated-diamond composites at 60 vol % diamond volume fraction. It is obvious in Fig. 5a that Ag/uncoated-diamond composites show a weak interfacial bonding with leaving obvious cracks/voids in the surrounding particles, which is mainly owing to the poor wettability between the diamond and Ag. In contrast, as shown in Fig. 5b, Ag/coated-diamond composites exhibit a considerably improved interfacial bonding, in which the trans-particle fracture of nearly all the diamonds is occurred. No clear pores and cracks can be found in this case. The occurrence of trans-crystalline fracture of diamonds suggests that the strength of interfacial bonding is larger than that of diamond. The microstructure analysis suggests that the formation of Cr7C3 carbides may greatly enhance the interfacial adhesion between the Ag matrix and the diamonds.
Fig. 5
Fracture surfaces of Ag/uncoated-diamond and Ag/coated-diamond composites at 60 vol % diamond volume fraction

Low CTE is an important thermal parameter for the composites used in TMMs, since a large difference in the CTE between the packaging materials and the components can lead to serious internal stresses and poor reliability of a device. Therefore, a decrease of the CTE may minimize the CTE mismatch between the packaging materials and components and improve the reliability of the electronic device. Figure 6 shows the CTE of the Ag/uncoated-diamond and Ag/coated-diamond composites as a function of diamond volume fraction. For the pure Ag, the CTE is 19.5 × 10−6/K. A monotonic decrease in CTEs is observed in both the Ag/uncoated-diamond and Ag/coated-diamond composites as the content of reinforcements increases, indicating the critical role of ultralow intrinsic CTE of diamond for CTE reduction. In addition, the CTE of Ag/uncoated-diamond at different diamond contents is in between 15.9 and 17.2 × 10−6/K showing a lower decrease in CTE of the composites compared to that of pure Ag matrix. In sharp contrast, Ag/coated-diamond composites show a dramatic CTE reduction with the increase of diamond content, being as low as 8.2 × 10−6 at 60 % diamond content. The weak bonding between uncoated diamond and Ag is believed to be a main reason for the low decrement of CTE in Ag/uncoated-diamond composites, while the presence of Cr7C3 coating provides strong interfacial strength, which helps to distribute expansion coefficient mismatch from the Ag matrix to diamond particles, leading to a much low CTE in Ag/coated-diamond composites.
Fig. 6
CTE of the Ag/uncoated-diamond and Ag/coated-diamond composites with various diamond volume fractions

The effect of the volume fraction of diamond particles on the CTE of the Ag/coated-diamond composites can be estimated by the Turner [21] model and Kerner [22] model, two approaches to be frequently used for describing the CTE behavior of the particulate composites with effective interfacial bonding. The model expression and material parameters can be found in Refs. [3, 23]. The solid line and the dotted line in Fig. 6 are the theoretically calculated values of the CTE with varying volume fraction of CNTs based on the Turner and Kerner models, respectively. Turner model only assumes a homogeneous strain in the composite and gives an overestimated experimental CTE reduction. The Kerner model, which considers both normal and shear stresses between fillers and matrix, thus gives a quite satisfactory estimation for the CTE data. The comparison results show that the combined factors such as ultralow CTE, high bulk modulus and shear modulus of diamond and good interfacial bonding between the diamond and Ag all contribute to the CTE reduction of composites, in which the good interfacial bonding plays a dominant role in decreasing CTE of Ag/diamond composites by acting as an effective load transfer bridge for helping the rigid diamond to greatly limit the thermal expansion of soft Ag.

High TC is usually a main desirable property of TMMs for application in electronic packaging. Figure 7 shows the TC of the composites as a function of diamond volume fraction. The TC of the pure Ag matrix is 425 W/mK. It is clear that the addition of uncoated diamonds in the Ag matrix composites does not show any TC enhancement. The measured TC values are even much lower than that of pure Ag. However, one can see a significant TC increase in Ag/coated-diamond composites with addition of the Cr7C3 coated diamonds. The TC of the Ag/coated-diamond composites reaches 695 W/mK at the 60 vol % diamond content, which is 1.64 times of measured value for pure Ag and twice that for Ag/uncoated-diamond composites. Owing to the poor wettability between uncoated diamonds and Ag matrix, diamond particles cannot be totally wrapped around by the Ag matrix, leaving behind the obviously voids at Ag-diamond interface, as shown in Fig. 5a. These voids, with an extremely low TC of ~0.026 W/mK [24], prevent the direct contact between the diamonds and Ag and thus act as the scattering centers for the thermal transport, causing the TC of the composites even much lower than that of the matrix. On the contrary, the improved wettability between coated diamonds and Ag matrix increases the Ag-diamond contact area considerably. The greater contact area eliminates the negative effect of voids, thus increases the path for phonon diffusion between the diamonds and Ag, providing a high TC enhancement in Ag/coated-diamond composites. In addition, the interfacial phonon scattering or the thermal boundary resistance (TBR) at the matrix-reinforcement interface is closely related to interfacial bonding state [25]. According to Fig. 5, the Ag/uncoated-diamond composites with uncoated diamonds exhibit interfacial debonding or weak interfacial adhesion, which causes a high level of TBR, and thus a much reduced TC. After surface treatment, the surface of the diamond particles is uniformly covered by Cr7C3 coating layer capable of reacting with diamond particles and wetting Ag matrix, resulting in a good interfacial adhesion between the particles and Ag matrix. The strong interfacial bonding leads to a significant reduction of the TBR in the overall composites, and thus facilitates the effective phonon transfer from the diamond to the Ag matrix, resulting in a high TC of the composites. TBR can be roughly calculated by the effective medium theory proposed by Hasselman and Johnson [26], given by:
Fig. 7

where K is the TC, the subscripts c, m and d refer to composite, matrix and reinforced particles, respectively. V p and a are the volume fraction and average radius of particles, respectively. Fitting this model (Fig. 8) by introducing material parameters (K m = 425 W/mK, K p = 1300 W/mK, a = 42.5 μm) reveals that the TBR in Ag/coated-diamond is in the range of 10−7–10−8 m2/KW, which is nearly one order of magnitude lower than that of Ag/uncoated-diamond composites (10−6–10−7 m2/KW), suggesting that the TBR of the Ag/diamond composites can be significantly reduced by careful engineering of the Cr7C3 carbides on the diamond surface.
Fig. 8
Prediction of the TC vs. TBR for the Ag/coated-diamond (black circles) and Ag/uncoated-diamond (red circles) composites obtained by Hasselman and Johnson model (Eq. 1)

In addition, the TBR of the Ag/coated-diamond composites due to the presence of interfacial coating layer can be characterized by R K = L/K carbide + R K1 + R K2 [14], where L and K carbide are the thickness and the TC of the interfacial carbide, respectively. R K1 and R K2 are the TBRs with the two bounding interfaces, as illustrated in Fig. 9. Therefore, the TC of the Ag/coated-diamond system is also very sensitive on the amount/thickness of carbides layer. The insufficient coating layer does not cover the entire interface leading to a partially weak interfacial bonding or high value of TBR. Also, the thick coating layer will cause the high thermal resistance of coating itself. Both can cause a degradation of composite TC. Therefore, a careful control and optimization of the amount of coating layer is crucial for a successful improvement in TC of the composites.
Fig. 9
Schematic illustration of the TBR (R K) of Ag/diamond composites with carbide coating layer

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: Metal/diamond composites have attracted substantial academic and industrial interest recent years in electrical packing field. The present work explores the possibility to improve Ag-diamond interfacial interaction by pre-coating diamonds with chromium carbide, which provides a good means to obtain a low CTE and high TC for Ag/diamond composites. SEM, XRD and XPS results showed that uniform chromium carbide layer with an only Cr7C3 phase was successfully coated onto the diamond particles. The recorded displacement vs. temperature curve during the SPS process indicated that coated diamonds facilitate the composite densification process by lowering the solid-state sintering temperature. Raman spectroscopy confirmed that there were no changes or deformations in the molecular structure of the diamonds or the composites for any of the processes. The Cr7C3 coating layer on diamond particles yielded a strong Ag-diamond interfacial bonding. Compared to Ag/uncoated-diamond composites, the Ag/coated-diamond composites showed a much reduced CTE and greatly enhanced TC at the same diamond volume fraction. The excellent thermal performance of present Ag/diamond composites with Cr7C3 coated diamond particles may offer a way to prepare a range of advanced metal matrix composites for thermal management applications.
